chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Abortion law should start from shared aims: protect human dignity, reduce preventable suffering, and keep medical care safe, timely, and grounded in clinical standards. It can acknowledge moral disagreement by permitting access early in pregnancy and allowing later restrictions only where they do not block emergency treatment and include clear, workable exceptions for serious health threats, sexual violence, and nonviable pregnancies, with decisions made in consultation with qualified clinicians and protected by strong privacy rules. To make any framework fair rather than coercive, governments should expand contraception and accurate education and provide real support for pregnancy, parenting, and adoption, while avoiding criminal penalties for patients or clinicians acting in good faith.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Abortion law should be grounded in medical evidence, patient privacy, and clinician-led decision-making, aiming to minimize harm while acknowledging that many attach moral value to developing life. It should protect timely access to safe care—especially early in pregnancy—and set any later limits in clear, workable terms with compassionate exceptions for threats to life or serious health, rape or incest, and fatal or severe fetal conditions. Policy should avoid criminalizing patients or clinicians acting in good faith, and instead pair rules with broad prevention and support: affordable contraception, comprehensive sex education, prenatal and postpartum care, childcare, and adoption resources so fewer people face crisis pregnancies.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Laws on abortion should start from shared goals—protecting human dignity, safeguarding women’s health, and reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies—by grounding rules in medical evidence and keeping urgent, time‑sensitive decisions primarily between patients and qualified clinicians. Policy can recognize moral concern for developing life by allowing reasonable, clearly defined limits later in pregnancy, while guaranteeing explicit exceptions for life‑threatening or serious health risks, rape or incest, and lethal fetal conditions, without criminalizing patients or clinicians acting in good faith. To make any framework humane and workable, governments should expand practical supports that prevent crisis pregnancies and make parenting a real option: affordable contraception, comprehensive sex education, prenatal and postpartum care, childcare, and adoption and counseling services.
